docs.lead_paragraph: Like many other schoolchildren, Claire and Stuart Bullen of Walnut Creek, Calif., have looked in awe at the people in the in-crowd and wondered, how do they do it? What is so special about them? But unlike many of their peers, Claire, 11, and Stuart, 8, do not aspire to be in that social tier: they think being popular means being unkind, making friends and then discarding them. This view may seem harsh, but several social scientists say it may not be totally off base. Researchers are just beginning to study the dynamics of popular students in elementary and middle school, and some early findings show that while most popular children are model students -- friendly, bright, athletic and cooperative -- a significant minority can be cruel.
docs.abstract: Researchers are just beginning to study dynamics of popular students in elementary and middle school, and some early findings show that while most popular children are model students--friendly, bright, athletic and cooperative--a significant minority can be cruel; Dr Philip C Rodkin, psychologist, says that some popular boys are extremely aggressive, intimidating and mean and that a lot of them are bullies; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: My patient Charlie did not show up for his appointment this month, an aberration for which I am deeply, selfishly grateful. It means that he is feeling well, since he never fails to check in at the first ache or sneeze. It also means that I get a little break from the relentless cross-examination that is a session in the office with Charlie. ''How long do I have, doc?'' he asks. ''Say a year, I guess, for sure, right? Am I right? Two?''

headline.main: When Patients Want to Know the Distance to Death's Door

docs.abstract: Dr Abigail Zuger comments on difficult questions facing a doctor when a patient with serious disease wants to know how long he has to live (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: This is high season for sore throats. One of my friends awakens with a scratchy throat nearly every morning on these cold winter days. Another said the other day that his throat felt sore and he guessed (correctly) that he was getting a cold. A third had gone back to bed with a throat so painful she could hardly talk, let alone swallow. Sore throat is a symptom, not a disease. In each case, there was a different cause that dictated a different treatment. The scratchy throat probably was a mechanical problem caused by dry, heated winter air and aggravated by my friend's tendency to breathe through her mouth when she sleeps. The very painful throat, on the other hand, turned out to be an infection serious enough to warrant a visit to the doctor.

headline.main: The Telltale Signs of Sore Throat Danger

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on sore throats, noting sore throat is a symptom of many medical conditions; many people seem to resist acknowleding and treating their sore throat pain; common causes of sore throats include infectious organisms, mechanical irritants and conditions like tumors that can result in serious halth consequences (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When Zora Brown got word that her pregnant, 29-year-old niece, Lea, had breast cancer, she decided it was high time for a serious family meeting. Breast cancer had cut a swath through Ms. Brown's family for four generations, striking all three of her sisters, her mother, grandmother, great-grandmother, three great-aunts and Ms. Brown herself. Now it appeared that the next generation, too, was under siege.

headline.main: Breast Cancer in Blacks Spurs Hunt for Answers

docs.abstract: Black women face more aggressive form of breast cancer; at time of unprecedented advancers, when overall death rates from breast cancer are declining, black women are 12 percent less likely than white women to get disease, but far more likely, once they get it, to die from it; among women with breast cancer, African-Americans are 50 percent more likely to get disease before age of 35, when tumors are more aggressive; charts; photos (L)
